M.G.L. c. 186, \u00a7 14.proposition: This is a civil action brought by the Plaintiff, Jessica Thompson, against her landlord, Michael Anderson, for breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment under Massachusetts law, specifically M.G.L. c. 186, § 14.

M.G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 1.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction over this matter pursuant to M.G.L. c. 231, § 1, as the damages sought are within the monetary jurisdiction of this Court.

M.G.L. c. 223, \u00a7 1.proposition: Venue is proper in Somerville District Court pursuant to M.G.L. c. 223, § 1, as the subject property is located in Somerville and the acts complained of occurred in this jurisdiction.

*AlZiab v. Mourgis*, 424 Mass. 847 (1997.proposition: Case law establishes that substantial interferences with a tenant’s sleep and peaceful use of their residence violate the covenant of quiet enjoyment.
*AlZiab v. Mourgis*, 424 Mass. 847 (1997.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses the covenant of quiet enjoyment in the context of lead paint liability and clarifies that at least negligent conduct by the landlord, with notice or reason to know of the condition, is required for a § 14 violation. It does not address sleep disruption, noise, or similar interferences with peaceful use of the premises, nor does it articulate any rule specific to substantial interference with sleep. Therefore it cannot be cited as authority for the specific proposition that substantial interference with a tenant’s sleep violates the covenant of quiet enjoyment.
*AlZiab v. Mourgis*, 424 Mass. 847 (1997.relevant_excerpt: Today we make clear what was implicit in those rulings: to support the imposition of liability under the quiet enjoyment statute, there must be a showing of at least negligent conduct by a landlord and violation of the lead paint statute alone is not sufficient to prove such negligence. Stated differently, to obtain relief under § 14 for a claim of lead paint poisoning it must be demonstrated that the landlord had notice of or reason to know of the presence of lead and failed to take appropriate corrective measures.

*Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).proposition: Case law establishes that substantial interferences with a tenant’s sleep and peaceful use of their residence violate the covenant of quiet enjoyment.
*Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).support_reasoning: The opinion squarely discusses the covenant/statutory right of quiet enjoyment and holds that a landlord is liable where its conduct causes serious interference with the tenant’s tenancy, adopting the standard of interferences that impair the character and value of the premises. The facts involve repeated nighttime flooding with water and sewage that forced the tenant out of bed and caused significant emotional distress, which the court recognizes as interference with quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14. This comfortably encompasses substantial interferences with sleep and peaceful residential use as violating quiet enjoyment, even though the damages award on that count was vacated as duplicative.
*Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).relevant_excerpt: “The phrase ‘quiet enjoyment’ is a familiar term in landlord-tenant law, signifying the tenant’s right to freedom from serious interferences with his tenancy — acts or omissions that ‘impair the character and value of the leased premises.’ Winchester v. O’Brien, 266 Mass. 33, 36 (1929) (quoting from Brande v. Grace, 154 Mass. 210, 212 [1891]). … The jury found in answer to a special question … that the water interfered with Solomon’s quiet enjoyment of her apartment. Therefore, Gem is liable under G. L. c. 186, § 14.”}

*Lodge v. Bern*, 328 Mass. 42 (1951).proposition: Courts in Massachusetts have held that a landlord’s inaction in the face of known disturbances by other tenants constitutes a breach of M.G.L. c. 186, § 14.
*Lodge v. Bern*, 328 Mass. 42 (1951).support_reasoning: The case concerns an insurance coverage dispute over an automobile liability policy and whether an exclusion for use as a public or livery conveyance applies. It does not involve landlord-tenant law, M.G.L. c. 186, § 14, or any issue about a landlord’s responsibility for disturbances caused by other tenants. Therefore, it cannot be cited as authority for the claimed proposition about landlord inaction constituting a breach of § 14.
*Lodge v. Bern*, 328 Mass. 42 (1951).relevant_excerpt: This bill is brought against Irene Bern and the Great American Indemnity Company, hereinafter called the insurer, to reach and apply the obligation of the insurer on a liability policy covering an automobile owned by Bern to the payment of a judgment for $20,000 and costs recovered in the United States District Court by the plaintiff against Bern as compensation for bodily injury suffered by the plaintiff on February 1, 1947, in an accident in which Bern’s automobile was involved on a public way of this Commonwealth.

*Berman & Sons v. Jefferson*, 379 Mass..proposition: Courts in Massachusetts have held that a landlord’s inaction in the face of known disturbances by other tenants constitutes a breach of M.G.L. c. 186, § 14.
*Berman & Sons v. Jefferson*, 379 Mass..support_reasoning: The opinion deals exclusively with breach of the implied warranty of habitability and rent abatement due to loss of heat and hot water, not with M.G.L. c. 186, § 14 or with disturbances caused by other tenants. There is no discussion of landlord inaction regarding tenant-on-tenant disturbances, nor any interpretation of § 14. Therefore, it cannot be cited as authority for the proposition that such inaction constitutes a breach of M.G.L. c. 186, § 14.
*Berman & Sons v. Jefferson*, 379 Mass..relevant_excerpt: "We must decide (1) whether a tenant must pay full rent without abatement when the landlord, acting without fault or bad faith, fails to maintain a dwelling in habitable condition and (2) whether the tenant’s obligation to pay full rent persists until the landlord has had a reasonable time to repair the defect. We hold that the tenant’s obligation abates as soon as the landlord has notice that premises fail to comply with the requirements of the warranty of habitability."

*Dartmouth v. Lilley*, 82 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: Defendant’s failure to take effective action concerning Plaintiff's complaints similarly constitutes a violation of Plaintiff’s rights.
*Dartmouth v. Lilley*, 82 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: The opinion is a Massachusetts criminal case about sufficiency of the evidence for possession of cocaine with intent to distribute. It does not involve any plaintiff complaints, any duty to respond to complaints, or any discussion of a defendant’s failure to take effective remedial action as a violation of rights. The proposition concerns a civil/rights-based duty to act on complaints, which is entirely unrelated to the issues and holdings in this opinion, so the case cannot support that proposition.
*Dartmouth v. Lilley*, 82 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: "The two basic elements for conviction of possession with the intent to distribute cocaine are (1) knowingly possessing the drug and (2) intending to transfer it physically to another person." (p. 768). The case analyzes whether the Commonwealth presented sufficient evidence of intent to distribute; it does not address any duty to respond to complaints or related rights violations.
